title.narrative: Life & Peace Institute´s Conflict Transformation Programme 2013-2016

description.narrative: LPI's overall objective is outlined in their vision of success: Conflict in the programme areas transformed, with narratives that drive conflict in Somalia demystified and deconstructed locally and internationally.

Insatsen avser stöd år 2013 -2016 till Liv- och Freds institutets Konfliktomvandlingsprogram (CTP). Målsättningen för programmet är att bidra till varaktig fred, säkerhet och utveckling i Stora sjö-regionen och Afrikas horn-regionen.

The objectives of the LPI Conflict Transformation Programme (2013-2016) contributes towards the achievement of sustainable peace, security and development in the Great Lakes and Horn of Africa regions.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Over the course of the past three years, the programme has generated evidence to challenge dominant narratives that drive conflict in Somalia and at the local and international level made accessible evidence that promotes alternative, more inclusive and local-led approaches in the complex context of South central Somalia. Key achivements include: - Target clans are now regularly engaging in community reconciliation processes to resolve conflicts and identify longer-term solutions in support of peace and stability. LPI and partners have supported a total of 54 intra-clan dialogues and 11 inter-clan dialogues. Approximately 21 peace agreements have been established and have resulted in improved resource sharing(over water and grazing lands), demobilisation of militias, and acceptance of community policing mechanisms and have led to more sustained periods of peace within and between clans in all five target locations.- Some clans are moving beyond project-supported dialogues and beginning to invest in conflict transformation initiatives directly, embracing a commitment to nonviolent approaches to conflict. While by the end of the programme it was only in Hiran that a community platform had been established, the foundations of community platforms have been created in the other programme implementation locations. Clans have begun to set in motion actions to make outcomes from individual peace agreements more permanent and to facilitate ongoing dialogues without the direct support of programme partners.In many cases the agreement of peace deals has contributed to the establishment of committees to oversee and steward thepeace process and ensure ongoing participation on dialogues. - Marginalised groups, including women and youth, have been given new opportunities to participate and contribute to clan-level peace and reconciliation processes. LPI, ZZF, SPL, and SWSO have, through negotiation and clan leader influencing,been able to augment the space for marginalised groups in dialogue processes,laying the foundation for a more holistic and sustainable peace. While this remained a challenge throughout the course of the programme, all partners worked with extra care to enhance the participation of these groups. For example, SPL engaged with women outside of the formal talks, using various strategies such as training and identification and engagement of key influential women. SWSO subverted the traditional patriarchal realm of peacebuilding by engaging women in an intra and inter-clan dialogueprocess, seeking buy-in through discussions with male community and government representatives. - In May 2016, LPI signed a MoU with a UK-based peacebuilding organisation Peace Direct to jointly explore collaboration on peacebuilding activities in Lower Jubba and conducted joint research to shed light on options and strategies for increasing women’s participation in peacebuilding processes in Jubbaland. LPI also launched a women-centredpeacebuilding process in Kismayo with the new partner SWSO and included in the design of LPI’s 2017-2020 Somalia programme an additional women-centred outcome, O3, Increase in women’s participation and influence on intra and interclan peace and reconciliation processes. - Increased networking with Somali policy actors is enabling LPI and partners to integrate policy advocacy work into peacebuilding programming as well as to inform relevant policy goals toward local, national, regional and international policy makers. - Space for civil society participation in peacebuilding has successfully been negotiated (although this is expected to remain an ongoing endeavour). - Enhanced trust and relationships built between and among communities has provided a foundation for communities to engage in the state-building process.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
